title: Goodness Gracious Me (TV series)
text:
Goodness Gracious Me is a <a href="BBC">BBC</a> <a href="English-language">English-language</a> <a href="sketch%20comedy">sketch comedy</a> show originally aired on <a href="BBC%20Radio%204">BBC Radio 4</a> from 1996 to 1998 and later televised on <a href="BBC%20Two">BBC Two</a> from 1998 to 2001. The ensemble cast were four <a href="British%20Asian">British Asian</a> actors, <a href="Sanjeev%20Bhaskar">Sanjeev Bhaskar</a>, <a href="Kulvinder%20Ghir">Kulvinder Ghir</a>, <a href="Meera%20Syal">Meera Syal</a> and <a href="Nina%20Wadia">Nina Wadia</a>. The show explored British Asian culture, and the conflict and integration between traditional <a href="South%20Asian%20culture">South Asian culture</a> and modern British life. Some sketches reversed the roles to view the British from a <a href="South%20Asia">South Asia</a>n perspective, and others poked fun at <a href="South%20Asian%20stereotypes">South Asian stereotypes</a>. In the television series, most of the <a href="White%20British">white</a> characters were played by <a href="Dave%20Lamb">Dave Lamb</a> and <a href="Fiona%20Allen">Fiona Allen</a>; in the radio series those parts were played by the cast themselves. Some of the white characters were also played by <a href="Amanda%20Holden">Amanda Holden</a> and <a href="Emma%20Kennedy">Emma Kennedy</a>.
The show's title and <a href="theme%20tune">theme tune</a> is a <a href="Bhangra%20%28music%29">bhangra</a> rearrangement of the <a href="Goodness%20Gracious%20Me%20%28song%29">comedy song of the same name</a>, originally performed by <a href="Peter%20Sellers">Peter Sellers</a> (portraying an <a href="Indian%20people">Indian</a> doctor, Ahmed el Kabir) and <a href="Sophia%20Loren">Sophia Loren</a>, reprising their characters from the 1960 film, "<a href="The%20Millionairess">The Millionairess</a>". Sellers sings the song in a stereotypical "cod-Indian" accent, acceptable as a comic device at the time but by the 1990s considered dated and belittling. Consequently, the show's original working title was "Peter Sellers is Dead"; this was changed as the cast admired Sellers' other work, as well as the fact that although Sellers' Indian doctor was a parody, the actor still portrayed him as a competent professional. (In her 1996 novel "<a href="Anita%20and%20Me">Anita and Me</a>", Syal had referred to British parodies of south Asian speech as "a goodness-gracious-me accent".)
The cast casually drop <a href="Punjabi%20language">Punjabi</a> and <a href="Hindi">Hindi</a> slang phrases into their speech, in the manner of many British Asians living in the UK.
The show won Best Entertainment at the <a href="Broadcasting%20Press%20Guild">Broadcasting Press Guild</a> Award and the Team Award from the <a href="Royal%20Television%20Society">Royal Television Society</a>, UK in 1999.
In March 2014, the BBC announced that the show would return with a special episode as part of celebrations of fifty years of <a href="BBC%20Two">BBC Two</a>. An India special was broadcast on BBC Two on 25 August 2015.
Parodies and references in the show.
Other parodies are based on shows such as "<a href="Animal%20Hospital">Animal Hospital</a>" (where members of lower castes take the place of the pets) and "<a href="Rough%20Guides">Rough Guides</a>" (where tourists from India visit and make unpleasant remarks about England).
Going for an English.
One of the best known sketches featured the cast "going out for an English" after a few <a href="lassi">lassi</a>s. They continually mispronounce the waiter's name, order the blandest thing on the menu (apart from one of them, who opts for the stronger option of a <a href="steak%20and%20kidney%20pie">steak and kidney pie</a>) and ask for 24 plates of chips. The sketch <a href="parody">parodies</a> English people "going out for an Indian" after drinking heavily, being rude to the waiter, demanding the spiciest thing available on the menu for show and ordering far too many <a href="papadum">papadum</a>s. This sketch was voted the 6th Greatest Comedy Sketch on a <a href="Channel%204">Channel 4</a> list show.
